metadata.case_name: Plaintiff (Appellant) v. Kontaru Naiko (Defendant No. 1) & Ors.

facts.text: Plaintiff obtained a registration certificate under s. 5 and r. 5 of the Orissa Money-Lenders Act, 1939 on March 31, 1952.
Defendants contended that the maximum capital for which the 1952 registration certificate was required was Rs. 2,000.
Plaintiff obtained another registration certificate in 1955 stating maximum capital of Rs. 8,000.
Plaintiff advanced loan of Rs. 6,000 to defendant No. 1 on May 19, 1954.
Plaintiff sued for recovery of Rs. 8,216 due on the promissory note executed by defendant No. 1.
Trial Court (Subordinate Judge, Berhampur) decreed the suit against defendants, holding defendants Nos. 2 and 3 liable only to the extent of assets of defendant No. 1.
Orissa High Court in First Appeal No. 61 of 1959 reversed trial court decree and dismissed the suit on April 11, 1962.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the registration of the appellant as a registered money-lender in March 1952 became void when he advanced a loan in excess of Rs. 2,000 in 1954.
Whether the appellant could not have advanced the loan in excess of the maximum capital for which the registration certificate was granted.
Retrospective operation of registration certificates of higher denomination obtained during the currency of a prior certificate.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in holding that registration became void upon advancing loan exceeding Rs. 2,000 and that appellant could not advance loan exceeding maximum capital in certificate.
Raised point on retrospective operation of 1955 higher denomination certificate.

respondent_arguments.text: Suit not maintainable as plaintiff advanced loan exceeding maximum capital of Rs. 2,000 in 1952 certificate, making registration void; thus even suit for Rs. 2,000 not maintainable.

court_reasoning.text: Question same as in Sant Saranlal v. Parsuram Sahu; relevant provisions of Orissa Act analogous to Bihar Acts; no specific provision in Act fixing maximum capital or voiding registration if exceeded.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules requiring mention of maximum capital do not imply registration becomes void if exceeded.

court_reasoning.text: Rules on application, fees, and higher certificates do not lead to conclusion that exceeding limit voids registration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Absence of specific provision in Act; not open to State Government to frame rule voiding registration.

court_reasoning.text: Not necessary to decide retrospective operation of higher certificate.

holdings.text: In absence of specific provision in Act providing for fixing maximum capital, not open to State to frame rule; rules do not make registration void if maximum capital exceeded.
Money-lender can advance loans exceeding maximum capital stated in registration certificate without voiding registration.

precedents_cited.relevance: Same question decided; provisions analogous to Bihar Money-Lenders Acts

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Money-Lenders Act, 1939 (Act III of 1939)
statutes_cited.relevance: Registration of money-lenders, validity for suits to recover loans, definitions of capital and registered money-lender, accounts, interest rates

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Money-Lenders Rules, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of maximum capital, application requirements, fees, form and higher denomination certificates

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held in favor of appellant, ruling that registration not voided by exceeding maximum capital; reversed High Court dismissal of suit.

key_quotes.text: "the registration of the money-lender will become void if he exceeds the limit of the maximum capital laid down in the registration certificate."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court rejects this conclusion of High Court

key_quotes.text: "Suit for recovery of loan maintainable by registered money-lenders only - A money-lender shall not be entitled to institute a suit for the recovery of a loan advanced by him after the date on which this section comes into force unless he was registered under this Act at the time when such loan was advanced"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key provision s. 8 on suit maintainability

key_quotes.text: "in the absence of any specific provision in the Act ... it was not open to the State Government to frame a rule in that regard"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on limits of rules vs. Act
